bestBHT.bht: In the face of idolatry, God assures Elijah that He has kept for Himself a faithful remnant who have not bowed down to Baal. This reveals that even during dark times, there are more supporters of God than we may realize. The mention of Baal, the sun-god representing the generative principle in nature, underscores the dichotomy between true worship and false idols. It reminds us that God will always preserve His chosen people, offering hope in the midst of corruption within the Church.

Henry Alford: I have left to myself seven thousand men."
The sense of the saying...is to show that all these were faithful men."
Who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath been His counsellor?
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: bowed the knee to Baal—not "the image of Baal,
according to the supplement of our version.
Albert Barnes: Such an answer, at such a time, would be full of comfort, and silence every complaint.
Amidst the general corruption and idolatry he had restrained a part, though it was a remnant.
This should lead us to hope that even in the darkest times in the church, there may be many more friends of God than we suppose.
Philip Schaff: The mistake of the latter in reading the verb is corrected by the Apostle."
‘left remaining’ brings out the thought that these had not been ‘killed'
‘Baal’ (signifying lord, ruler) was the sun-god, representing the active generative principle in nature.
Archibald T. Robertson: The answer of God (ο χρηματισμος). An old word in various senses like χρηματιζω, only here in N.T."
To Baal (τη Βααλ). Feminine article. In the LXX the name Βααλ is either masculine or feminine.
The explanation is that the Jews put Bosheth (αισχυνη, shame) for Baal and in the LXX the feminine article occurs because αισχυνη is so, though here the LXX has the masculine τω.
John Gill: I have reserved to myself; for his worship and service, to be partakers of his grace, inheritors of his kingdom, to show forth his praise, and for his name's sake, for his honour and glory.
These he reserved in eternal election, in the council and covenant of peace; separated them in time from others by his grace, and preserved them from the general defection and apostasy.

The apostle's view in mentioning this instance is to show, that when the church and cause of God are at the lowest, God has always some true worshippers of him; and that he never casts away his foreknown people.
John Wesley: To Baal — Nor to the golden calves.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Romans 11:4, the Apostle Paul quotes from the Old Testament about a remnant of faithful men who had not bowed down to Baal. The answer of God to Elijah's complaint is a reminder that even in the darkest times, there are always more friends of God than we realize. Amidst the general corruption and idolatry, God had reserved for Himself a group who remained loyal to Him. This demonstrates His sovereignty and faithfulness in preserving His chosen ones. The mention of Baal, the sun-god representing the generative principle in nature, highlights the contrast between the true worship of God and the false worship of idols. Ultimately, this passage serves as a reminder that our hope in God should be unwavering, even when the church appears to be at its lowest, for He will never cast away His foreknown people.

In the face of idolatry, God assures Elijah that He has kept for Himself a faithful remnant who have not bowed down to Baal. This reveals that even during dark times, there are more supporters of God than we may realize. The mention of Baal, the sun-god representing the generative principle in nature, underscores the dichotomy between true worship and false idols. It reminds us that God will always preserve His chosen people, offering hope in the midst of corruption within the Church.

In Romans 11:4, God reveals to Elijah that amidst pervasive idolatry, He had reserved for Himself a faithful remnant who had not bowed down to Baal. This passage serves as a reminder that even in the darkest times, God has hidden supporters who remain loyal to Him. The mention of Baal, the sun-god representing generative power, emphasizes the distinction between true worship and false idols. It assures us that God never abandons His chosen people, giving us hope during times of spiritual decline.

In the midst of prevailing idolatry, God assures Elijah of a faithful remnant that has not bowed down to Baal. This highlights the existence of hidden supporters during the darkest times, reminding us that there are more friends of God than we may realize. The mention of Baal, symbolizing the generative principle in nature, emphasizes the contrast between true worship and false idols. It reassures us that God preserves His chosen people, instilling hope even in the face of spiritual decline.

In Romans 11:4, God reveals His reservation of a faithful remnant amidst widespread idolatry. This demonstrates that even in the darkest times, there are more friends of God than we realize, offering hope in the church's decline. The mention of Baal, symbolizing the generative principle in nature, contrasts the true worship of God with false idols. This passage serves as a reminder that God never forsakes His chosen people and preserves them in His grace, honoring His name.
